Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of a Compute Cluster for High-Fidelity Simulations of Gravitational Wave Sources -- Facilitating LIGO and Enabling Multi-Messenger Astronomy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5). The award enables the acquisition of a computer cluster to allow the simulation of groundbreaking models of astronomical systems to yield high-fidelity, robust, quantitative predictions for multi-messenger astronomy in the form of gravitational waveforms, neutrino signatures, and electromagnetic signals.

Gravitational waves (GWs) are ripples in the structure of spacetime that propagate across the universe at the speed of light. The NSF-funded Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory (LIGO) is searching for these waves, which encode otherwise inaccessible details of their sources. This new information will be enriched and complemented by electromagnetic and neutrino observations of those sources, making multi-messenger astronomy a reality. Codes have been developed to take advantage of the growth in available computing power to allow improved, accurate modeling of several potential sources of gravitational waves, including double star systems containing black holes and/or neutron stars and the collapse of massive stars to yield supernovae.

The cluster, to be located at Caltech's Center for Advanced Computing Research, will consist of approximately 2000 cores and approximately 100 TeraBytes (TB) of disk to start, with upgrades to approximately 325 TB by the end of the project. The machine be will be used by the Caltech/Cornell numerical relativity collaboration and by the Caltech Computational Astrophysics Group and collaborators at Princeton University, the University of Maryland and Louisiana State University. The cluster will concentrate on simulations where rapid turnaround time is required, on the development/testing of code to be run on (slow-turnaround, but much larger) TeraGrid/Lab resources, and on analysis/visualization of results obtained on TeraGrid/Lab machines as well as on the cluster itself. Graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral scholars will participate in the research and be trained to use the cluster. The cluster will foster extensive research collaboration across seven institutions and will significantly enhance the future scientific output of LIGO. The results of simulations performed on this cluster will be disseminated to scientists in all fields and to the general public, via web presentations, public lectures, articles, and movies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI-R2 grant supported the purchase of the high-performance compute cluster "Zwicky", which has been deployed in 2010 at the Caltech Center for Advanced Computing research and has since been upgraded and extended thrice. Now in its final state, Zwicky has 2400 Intel Xeon compute cores, 4.7 terabytes of main memory, and about 400 terabytes of spinning disk storage.

Zwicky is a crucial instrument, supporting the research of the Simulating eXtreme Spacetimes (SXS) project, a collaboration of groups at Caltech, Cornell, the Canadian Institute for Theoretical Astrophysics (CITA), Washington State University, and CSU Fullerton.

The research enabled by Zwicky can be categorized into three main areas: (1) Simulations of double black hole systems that inspiral and merge ("binary black holes"), (2) simulations of binaries involving neutron stars (either  double neutron star or a black-hole--neutron-star systems), and (3) simulations of the collapse and explosion of massive stars in core-collapse supernovae.

Zwicky has enabled breakthrough science in these areas in multiple ways:

It enabled the team to carry out full, extremely long and extremely accurate simulations of binary black hole mergers with the SXS Spectral Einstein Code (SpEC). SpEC is a numerical relativity simulation code -- it implements Einstein's equations and time-evolves them forward from prescribed initial conditions. Simulations on Zwicky (and on NSF XSEDE and CITA supercomputers)  led to a catalog of 171 high-accuracy simulations that yielded predictions of gravitational wave signals to be detected by NSF's Advanced LIGO gravitational-wave detectors (see figure "171 Numerical Relativity Gravitational Waveforms"). This is the largest catalog of such high-accuracy waveforms ever generated. These waveforms will help calibrate LIGO's search algorithms via so-called calibrated search templates.

Zwicky has also been a crucial resource for cutting-edge simulations of the mergers of neutron stars and black holes. In the merger, the neutron star is typically disrupted by the black hole and an accretion disk forms that is extremely hot (of order few times 10^10 Kelvin) and radiates neutrinos (see Figure "Simulation of the Disruption of a Neutron Star by a Black Hole"). It is believed that such neutron-star--black-hole mergers may power a class of cosmic gamma-ray bursts. The SXS collaboration, enabled by Zwicky, was able to carry out a large set of such merger simulations, using initial configurations (black hole, neutron star masses and spins) that are believed to be the most likely to occur in nature. This led to new predictions of the dependence of the remnant accretion disk mass on black hole spin and mass ratio between black hole and neutron star. Moreover, the SXS team carried out the first ever such merger simulation that accounted for the emission of neutrinos and the consequential cooling of the accretion disk after the merger.

Finally, Zwicky has been important for simulations extending our knowledge of how massive stars collapse and explode and how black holes form in stellar collapse. Such stellar collapse simulations are too large (that is, need too much memory and compute power) to be carried out on Zwicky directly. Nevertheless, Zwicky has been a crucial resource for the development of the code for these simulations, for testing the code, and for the "staging" of the very large simulations, which have been carried out at national supercomputing centers (e.g., on NSF's XSEDE network).
